item.title: Critic’s Notebook: In a Rediscovered Trove of Art, a Triumph Over the Nazis’ Will
item.description: A horde of art missing since the Nazi era yields lessons about the vagaries of survival.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:description: Clockwise from left, a self-portrait by Otto Dix, who was despised by Hitler; a painting by Max Liebermann; and a picture of a woman by Matisse.

item.title: Indian Craft Is Lofted Toward Mars, Trailed by Pride and Questions
item.description: The launch was a major step in India’s hopes to become the first country in Asia to reach Mars.
item.dc:creator: By HARTOSH SINGH BAL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Explosions Near Communist Party Building in China
item.description: A series of explosions outside a Communist Party building in a northern Chinese city injured at least one person, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: 3 Senators Suspended in Expenses Scandal
item.description: The three, Mike Duffy, Pamela Wallin and Patrick Brazeau, were appointed by Prime Minister Stephen Harper.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Argentina Finds a Dictatorship’s Secret Records
item.description: The discovery of secret documents from the military dictatorship that led Argentina from 1976 to 1983 provides rare insight into the persecution of intellectual figures.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Afghan Militant Group Faces Unusual Discontent
item.description: The militant Haqqani network’s war against the Soviets is still spoken of in reverential tones in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, but support has turned to resentment in some corners.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Christoph Bangert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zadran Valley of eastern Afghanistan, which has been a historical stronghold of the Haqqani network.

item.title: U.S. Is Losing Advantage in Spying, Report Says
item.description: A congressional panel charged that the United States intelligence agencies’ research-and-development efforts were disorganized and unfocused.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
National Commission for the Review of the Research and Development Programs of the United States Intelligence Community
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Mali: France Says It Will Not Delay Troop Withdrawal
item.description: France will stick to its timetable for withdrawing troops from Mali despite a resurgence in violence and the killing of two French journalists last weekend, Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Envoy Sent to North Korea to Push for Talks
item.description: China said Tuesday that it had sent its top envoy to North Korea this week to push for the resumption of talks on denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: Diplomats Fail to Agree on Details for Syria Peace Talks
item.description: Senior U.S., Russian and U.N. diplomats could not agree on a date for peace talks, nor were they able to decide on which countries should participate in the talks.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: After Outside Pressure, Rebels in Congo Lay Down Their Arms
item.description: The surrender offered new hope for a region where conflict has gone on for so many years that it has often come to seem almost inevitable.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:credit: Pete Muller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children played on a destroyed M-23 tank last week near Kibumba, north of Goma.

item.title: German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art
item.description: The first glimpse of the collection brought astonishment but also anger and the initial stirrings of what will likely be a long battle over who owns the works.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: The Munich apartment building where the authorities were said to have found about 1,400 works of art that were confiscated under the Nazis or sold cheaply by owners trying to flee Hitler.

item.title: The Lede: ‘I Have Smoked Crack Cocaine,’ Toronto’s Mayor Admits on Camera
item.description: Toronto Mayor Rob Ford stunned constituents and his own staff on Tuesday by telling a scrum of reporters, “Yes, I have smoked crack cocaine.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Prince Charles May Have Unfair Tax Edge, Report Says
item.description: British lawmakers raised questions about certain exemptions for the Duchy of Cornwall on revenue generated from the land, saying they may create an “unlevel playing field.”
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WERDIGIER

item.title: Lens Blog: A Congolese Rebellion Routed, a Photographer’s Work Continues
item.description: While the M23 rebels of Congo send signals of peace, the photographer Pete Muller, who has been documenting the conflict, will continue his work there exploring notions of masculinity.
item.category: Open Society Institute of Southern Africa
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: E.U. Predicts Anemic Growth and High Unemployment in 2014
item.description: Economic growth in 2014 should hit 1.1 percent in the euro area and 1.4 percent across the European Union and continue to strengthen in 2015.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Olli Rehn, the European Union’s commissioner for economics and monetary affairs, said growth this year is expected to flatline in the 28 countries of the Union.

item.title: Toronto Mayor Admits Smoking Crack, but Won’t Step Down
item.description: After months of denials, Mayor Rob Ford told reporters that he had “probably” tried crack cocaine “in one of my drunken stupors.” He later apologized to city residents, but refused to resign.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Iranian Minister Says Nuclear Deal Is Possible This Week
item.description: Two days before talks over Iran’s disputed nuclear program resume in Geneva, the country’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, sounded an optimistic note.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Few Eager to Talk Peace in Syria, but a Mediator Won’t Stop
item.description: Lakhdar Brahimi’s latest mission — starting Syria peace talks — has proved to be among the most stubborn of the many conflicts he has mediated on behalf of the United Nations.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Residents of Duma, outside Damascus, searched the site of what antigovernment activists said was an airstrike by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: The Lede: Reaction on the Streets and Online as Morsi Appears in Court
item.description: Video of Egypt’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, in court was broadcast on state television and widely shared online.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and LIAM STACK

item.title: Toronto Mayor Admits Crack Use
item.description: Mayor Rob Ford said Tuesday he smoked crack “probably a year ago” when he was in a “drunken stupor,” an admission that follows months of accusations during which he has refused to step down.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Mideast, Kerry Tries to Nudge Peace Talks Along
item.description: An absence of progress on core issues and grousing by Israeli and Palestinian officials about each other’s motives suggest talks are sputtering.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Letter From Africa: Behind Those Fast Growth Rates, Rising Inequality
item.description: There is a disquieting reality behind the “Africa Rising” narrative: The total number of people living in extreme poverty has increased.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Palestinian Inmate With Cancer Dies in Israeli Hospital
item.description: The death of the prisoner, a 22-year-old man who had leukemia, prompted accusations of medical malpractice by Palestinian leaders.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: November 5
item.description: India launched its first mission to Mars on Tuesday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: India's first spacecraft to Mars taking off from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh.
